title: Will of Ancients and Hextech Gunblade
body:
I am not sure if WOTA should be more of an independent item, or if it should stay as a cheap mid game alternative for Hextech until you reach full build. The Active and AD outweighs the 10% CDR for champions who use WOTA.

{{champion:24}} {{champion:84}} {{champion:82}} {{champion:28}}{{champion:105}}{{champion:55}}   These Champions all benefit more from {{item:3146}} due to their AD Ratios/ Auto attack dependencies 
{{champion:8}} {{champion:9}} These Champions benefit more from {{item:3152}} as casters 

As {{champion:82}} I build {{item:3152}} as my second item as it's cheaper and very powerful early game where as {{item:3146}} is 900 gold more so I leave it for after my full build and replace {{item:3152}} with it. I just feel that {{item:3152}} can be more of a stand alone item and more powerful on it's own. I think it should have more AP than Hextech so it's more appealing to mage casters without AD ratios. So if you want to replace it with Hextech you lose AP to gain AD/Lifesteal/Slow and Active. 

New [**2935 Gold** ]{{item:3152}} 100 AP, 10% CDR, 20% Spell Vamp


Current [**2500 Gold** ]{{item:3152}} 80 AP, 10% CDR, 20% Spell Vamp

Current [**3400**] {{item:3146}} 40 AD, 80 AP, 10% Life steal, 20% Spell Vamp
UNIQUE: Deals 150 (+ 40% AP) magic damage and slows the target champion's movement speed by 40% for 2 seconds. 60 second cooldown. (700 range)

I think WotA could use one or both of 20 more AP (making it a 100+ AP item with CDR, which we no longer have (RIP DFG)) and 50% mana regen, which would make it a sort of contender with Morellonomicon/Athene's Unholy Grail in the mana regen+AP+CDR area, while having much less CDR and mRegen while giving you sustain in the form of spellvamp.

Even more amped up we could see something like

120 AP
15% CDR
20% Spellvamp

for a 4th (5th counting Seraph's Embrace) 120 AP item, and a heavy AP item with CDR (which we no longer have) and more than one item with x5% CDR (which the game is sorely lacking imo).

Heck, i'd love to see it with 

100AP
15% CDR
20% Spellvamp
Unique passive: some sort of mana-on-hit return thingy.

As it is currently, it doesn't really do anything useful unless you've got some other spellvamp to stack it with, or otherwise manage to end up with 10% CDR missing, need the sustain and can deal with the low AP..

Most of the time though, you're just gonna go with Gunblade if you want spellvamp because it gives you as much AP and spellvamp, but gets you some AD (which always help) and lifesteal (which is sorta neat) on top of the brilliant active.

---

The main problem with spellvamp in general, is that it requires you to hit too many abilities, and for most mages their good spells go off too early in the battle for there to be much effect from it, unless you can stack oodles (with innate spellvamp like Morgana or Akali) or if you have another good way of proccing it (like Jax with his ult proccs and short CD AP scaling abilities).

I don't like the idea of adding mana regen... Vlad, Kennen, etc already have a limited enough pool of AP items that wouldn't waste their gold on a useless (for them) stat without having their sustain item join the ranks.

I'd say boost the AP on it, make it more relevant stat-wise for a full build. 100AP sounds reasonable without infringing on the 120AP Club's territory.

They want Spell vamp to remain unviable, because it is inherently unbalanceable and broken as a statistic. One way to keep it unviable is to make it so one option is so outlandishly overpriced that almost nobody gets it (gun blade) and the other is kept with moderately mediocre stats so that isn't that great even when you can get it early (WotA).

Spell vamp as a stat is something that has to be worked directly into a champion's kit, like Ahri's passive, or Cass's twin fang self heal, or Swains ultimate heal, which all heal for a flat amount + AP scaling, rather than actually scaling with damage dealt, because every single spell in the game is different unlike AAs and lifesteal, which is much healthier as a stat.

Spells can have *sooooo* many different variables in them that spell vamp is often beyond broken on a certain character and completely unreliable on another, thus their only solution (outside removing it, which they don't want to do because they'd have to rework several champions) is to leave it absolutely useless. Spells have different: range, cooldown, cost, width, AoE, targeting type, damage type, Damage application method, secondary effects, CC, personal utility, allied affects, and reliability (point and click vs skill shot vs PBAoE vs auto target). Lifesteal *always* works on *everyone* who buys it, because everyone has a physical damage auto attack that in a standard scenario always hits for the same damage as everyone else's if they have the same AD attacking the same target. Spell vamp doesn't.
Spellvamp is not nearly as broken as you make it out to be.

Not right now, *because it is so underpowered that nobody uses it*. Maybe you weren't around back when spell vamp was strong, but Champs like Akali, Katarina, and Mordekaiser were literally immortal as long as they could roll their face on their keyboard. 

Spell vamp on a kit, like Morgana's passive, Ryze's ultimate, or other built in sources are totally balanceable, but an openly available source off spell vamp in it's current state (or the state it was in back when WotA was strong) is inherently broken.

Obviously champions that do high damage, especially high burst damage, are going to benefit the most from it, and it gets reaaaally ugly when they stop having to worry about their own HP because they just need to combo someone to get most of it back.

> I am not sure if WOTA should be more of an independent item, or if it should stay as a cheap mid game alternative for Hextech until you reach full build. 

Cheap mid-game item, 100%.

Spell vamp currently has 2 main issues for why you wouldn't get it:

1) if you're so ability-reliant you're going spell vamp over life steal, running OoM is really, really bad. Mana sustain > HP sustain during the lanning phase of most champions that could make use of spell vamp.
This favors a cheaper item for fitting spell vamp into a build as an alternative, as there's a pull for another stat first and a clear drawback.

You'll also generally notice the vast majority of spell spell-vamp users are manaless or can utilize manaless abilities for spell vamp:

{{champion:84}} {{champion:55}} {{champion:8}} {{champion:82}} {{champion:68}} {{champion:24}} {{champion:20}} 

(Jax's Grandmaster applies on-hit effects and is a 100% in-effect passive skill, Nunu's passive allows him to cast a manaless spell after so many auto-attacks).

---------------------
2) {{item:3157}} is better.

Sustained damage champions rely on life steal to sustain through a fight come late-game, allowing a glass-cannon build the durability it needs to be appealing (rather than going bruiser build on everything like you would in a typical RPG).
Hourglass offers a burst of defense for burst casters, so they can burst and then have the CDR window they need to burst again (or counteract getting bursted).

Considering the power Hourglass can offer, it's fair to say it's better than life-steal in several scinarios, a {{champion:9}} with Hourglass can fairly easily cause an Ace, a Fidd with spell vamp will probably tend to be underwhelming.

---------------------- 

Anyways - if WotA is going to appeal to AP champions as a source of in-combat defense or lane-sustain, it needs to be cheap enough to merit diverting to on occasion within a {{item:3165}} {{item:3157}}  path.

---------
---------
 
On to your suggested change:

> New [**2935 Gold** ]{{item:3152}} 100 AP, 10% CDR, 20% Spell Vamp

This seems more like diss-incentive to get the item over a minor buff.

The average champion in the average game of LoL ends the game with 11,000 gold - which works out to about 1k for boots, three major 3k items, and 1k in the bank when someone's Nexus explodes.

So - there is little value in an item being "slot efficient" when it comes to LoL, because you'll rarely run out of space before a game ends. 

Which is the only advantage stat-sticks you can get with base item (or mostly base item) components really accomplishes.

Otherwise, you're pushing another item that offers AP and CDR 435 gold down the game time to it's completion, setting access to it's unique passive/active effects further back.

The 10% CDR boost just doesn't strike me as very worth it in this context, as the 435 bonus is 20 AP in the most cost-inefficient item tier of cheap base item components.
CDR in particular is a pretty awful stat to tack onto items willy-nilly, because it becomes useless when you hit the 40% cap, which isn't particularly hard to reach in any particular build. Sometimes it requires CDR boots or runes, but if you really want CDR maxed on someone like {{champion:9}} that scales extremely well with that stat, why Not get CDR maxed ASAP by using boots and runes with CDR on them while pushing things like M Pen into later-game itemization?
